Award.AwardTitle: Comparative biogeography and diversification of birds on Madagascar
Award.AbstractNarration:
Islands are natural laboratories for studying the evolutionary and ecological processes of how species colonize and diversify in novel environments. The island of Madagascar is a biodiversity hotspot that is renowned for its distinctive avifauna -- an exceptional diversity of bird species found nowhere else. This project uses Madagascar as a model to address a fundamental question in biology: why some groups become much more diverse than others over time. The current bird fauna of Madagascar is the result of several independent colonizations from surrounding regions over historical time. Despite arriving in Madagascar millions of years ago, only half the native lineages have subsequently speciated within this large island. This project will focus on a comprehensive investigation of the poorly-studied bird diversity on Madagascar to determine what causes some groups to diversify while others fail to speciate. The study will produce a more accurate assessment of species diversity and diversification patterns, which is crucial for subsequent conservation measures in this highly threatened landscape. This project will promote international collaborations, education and training from high-school to postdoctoral stages, conservation policy, and public outreach activities.

With a strong collaboration of international scientists of diverse backgrounds and expertise, this project will examine all 43 endemic terrestrial avian lineages, including 14 independent radiations, using phylogenetic, biogeographic, and phenotypic data. This study has three main objectives. First, a robust foundation of systematic and biogeographic information for Malagasy avian lineages and their close relatives will be developed to provide more accurate assessments of species diversity within Madagascar, as well as insight into the timing and routes of colonizations. Second, analyses of how and why lineages change in ecology and morphology upon colonization of novel environments will be conducted. These analyses will include large-scale characterization of morphology, plumage, and climatic niche across Malagasy endemic species and their continental relatives to determine the importance of shared and clade-specific evolutionary responses to common environmental settings. Third, predictability of within-island speciation and adaptive radiation will be determined. The research will investigate the probability of radiation after colonization as a function of numerous predictors, including evolutionary lability of trophic morphology, environmental tolerance, and the intrinsic "speciation potential" of individual clades. This project is a novel approach towards a comprehensive analysis of a biota and has broad implications for understanding the disparity in species richness across the evolutionary tree of life.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Madagascar is a biodiversity hotspot with many unique lineages found nowhere else in the world. The main goal of this project was to fill a critical gap in our knowledge of the endemic birds of this island by conducting a comprehensive investigation of their evolutionary relationships, origins, and diversification patterns. This study produced genomic data for over 1000 birds including many species that have never had their DNA sequenced before. We also characterized the phenotypic or outward features of these birds to build one of the largest datasets of morphological variation across a bird community. This is a tremendous effort towards a greater understanding of these species using modern analytical tools. 

Our studies resulted in valuable scientific information for both biology and conservation. Using multifaceted data, we were able to produce a more accurate assessment of the number of distinct species of birds in Madagascar. Our analyses resulted in 20% more species than listed in the current taxonomy. We examined patterns of phenotypic and genetic variation across the island to better understand how birds respond to the different habitats. With fine-scale information of multiple species across the island, we were able to examine how birds adapted to the different types of environments and were impacted by past geographic changes. Furthermore, we examined evolutionary relationships to deduce the origins of Malagasy birds to investigate how birds changed and speciated when they colonized Madagascar. Our studies showed that several lineages originated from distant landmasses like Asia rather the more proximate Africa. Understanding their origins and evolutionary relationships is key to analyzing how and what features of species change in response to new environments. Large comparative studies like this address key questions in biology ? such as how species diversify and why some lineages are more diverse than others ? as well as crucial information for conservation ? such as how many species there are and how can we predict their responses to future changes.

This project was an international collaboration across multiple institutions. The grant supported the activities of more than 35 scientists in the United States and Madagascar. We provided training opportunities for 4 high-school students and 15 undergraduates to gain research experiences. In addition, we trained 3 MS graduate students in the US and 2 PhD students in Madagascar, all of whom conducted research projects on Madagascar birds. Our project supported 4 recent college graduates with research technician positions to gain experiences necessary for graduate school ? three of these students are now in competitive PhD graduate programs studying Ecology and Evolutionary Biology. Finally, the grant supported 1 postdoctoral fellow and 6 collaborators. In total, the grant supported 23 women and 10 members of underrepresented communities in science.

Project participants were involved in a multitude of research activities as well as communicating results in various venues. Participants had opportunities to present their studies at scientific conferences and invited lectures. We produced several scientific publications describing our analyses with more in preparation. Data from this project formed the basis of teaching material for three different university courses. 

A major accomplishment of this project is the tremendous amount of new information generated for the unique birds of Madagascar, including genomic, morphometric, plumage, ecological, and geographic data. Furthermore, the approach of this study was to extract invaluable information from historical museum specimens using innovative methods and modern technologies (e.g., Next-generation sequencing, digital imaging, micro-CT scanning) as well as conducting new surveys to acquire current observations of birds in their natural environments. In addition to published analyses, the data are archived and available for scientists and conservation managers. We will continue to use the data assembled for this project for various research and education purposes for many years into the future.
